node.title: Republicans Have a Golden Opportunity. They Will Probably Blow It.
node.description: The partyâ€™s good fortune in avoiding profound punishment for all its follies is the reason  those follies will probably continue.
node.content: ["Last weekend I considered what the Democratic Party should expect from politics after Covid \u2014 the hope of revived popularity for Joe Biden under return-to-normalcy conditions, the danger that the left-tilting party might be losing ground across multiple different demographic groups. Now, after an interlude of giving thanks, let\u2019s consider how post-Covid politics might look from the Republican side.", "Republicans have a lot to be thankful for. In the years since George W. Bush their party has staggered around without a governing ideology, veering from one style of fantasy politics to another, and twice nominated a ridiculously unfit reality-television star for the presidency. Yet through it all the party has never collapsed, never fallen more than a little distance out of power and almost always retained a certain capacity to block the Democrats, which is the only thing its constituencies can agree on.", "This pattern seems unlikely to be broken even if Biden\u2019s poll numbers bounce back across 2022 and 2023. In that scenario Republicans will still probably narrowly recapture the House of Representatives, returning to the position that they held immediately after last November\u2019s election \u2014 as a minority coalition, but a large one rather than a rump, which thanks to its structural advantages can always hope to hold at least part of Congress and ride a few lucky breaks into the White House.", "But in a way, that advantage is also the core Republican weakness, and the party\u2019s good fortune in avoiding profound punishment for all its follies is the reason those follies will probably continue. The problems in the Democratic Party \u2014 the danger that its progressive turn is costing it conservative-leaning minority votes, even as anti-Trump suburban voters could swing back to the G.O.P. \u2014 create an opportunity for Republicans to win real popular majorities at the national level, on the scale of Bush in 2004 if not quite Ronald Reagan. But the fact that they don\u2019t need to be a majority coalition to exercise a certain power means that they\u2019re more likely to choose badly, and stay roughly where they are.", "The alternative, the best-case post-Covid scenario for the party, was visible in Glenn Youngkin\u2019s Virginia campaign, which essentially blended elements from Donald Trump in 2016 and 2020 with Mitt Romney in 2012, while shedding the baggage that kept both men from winning popular-vote majorities. Youngkin has a Romney-esque persona \u2014 the corporate suit and genial family man \u2014 but where the man from Bain Capital ended up captive to party dogma on taxes and entitlement cuts, the former Carlyle Group executive promised higher education spending and tax cuts that benefit the lower-middle class, playing against the corporate-Republican and supply-side stereotypes.", "Meanwhile, Youngkin imitated Trump not just in his relatively populist promises but also in his willingness to pick cultural fights \u2014 in this case, on critical race theory in schools \u2014 that other moderate Republicans might shy away from. But then in most other ways he was an anti-Trump: decent rather than bullying, reasonable rather than paranoid, keeping conspiracism at a distance, reassuringly competent rather than apocalyptic.", "So that\u2019s all the G.O.P. needs nationally to fully exploit its post-Covid opportunities \u2014 a more populist economic agenda, a willingness to take the fight to the progressive left (but with a smile) and an end to Trumpian conspiracism.", "But do enough actors in the party really want that combination? At the elite level there is a clutch of politicians and candidates who keep groping for a more populist agenda and a group of nationalist intellectuals who think they\u2019re on the cusp of imposing one upon the party. But there is still a larger group of lawmakers, strategist and donors who are very comfortable having no agenda whatsoever, or falling back on the familiarity of upper-bracket tax cuts and pretend budget cuts as soon as they\u2019re restored to power.", "Among the party\u2019s voters, activists and media personalities, meanwhile, there remains a clear appetite not for the Youngkin-style appropriation of certain parts of Trumpism, but for Donald Trump in full \u2014 nourished by the plausible belief that populists and social conservatives can\u2019t entirely trust more-corporate Republicans, the implausible belief that Trump\u2019s nastiness helped him more than it hurt him, the false belief that he actually won the 2020 election, plus the very America-in-2021 desire for politics to be high-stakes TV entertainment rather than boring attempts to cobble together governing majorities.", "And here\u2019s the thing: Between the Democratic Party\u2019s weaknesses, Biden\u2019s age and the unimpressiveness of his possible successors, Republicans could very easily be competitive in 2024 while renominating Trump and campaigning on a purely negative agenda.", "Sure, they can\u2019t expect to govern effectively that way, and they\u2019d be throwing away a potentially golden opportunity. But in the end the race would be close, there would be some exciting constitutional-crisis possibilities in the aftermath, and if the Democrats pulled it out, well, their majorities would be slim and 2026 would be just around the corner.", "And if there\u2019s anything we\u2019ve learned over the past 15 years, it\u2019s that the chance to enjoy a little bit of power without any real responsibility is impossible for Republicans to resist."]
